cat:name.gco:CharacterString: Feature Catalog for the Landscape-Level Ecological Assessment and Inventory database (LLEIAdb)

cat:scope.gco:CharacterString: LLEIA is a compilation database that sources data from several distinct collection sources, where each data source is housed in its own schema. The schemas available within this database are 1) The Natural Resource Inventory (NRI) Grazing Land schema, also known as Landscape Monitoring Framework (LMF) schema, 2) The U.S. Dept. of Agriculture (USDA) Agricultural Research Service (ARS) Jornada Experimental Range's Database for Inventory, Monitoring, and Assessment (DIMA) 3) LLEIA's own custom schema for plant/soil ecological monitoring data. Metadata for DIMA and LMF schemas are not provided as those schemas are not maintained by the author (with the exception of custom non-native schema table present for database functionality reasons). LLEIA's custom schema (eco) tables are documented. Data from the other two schemas are converted to the LLEIA schema through the use of materialized views and can be found in the public schema. Metadata for the materialized views in the public schema are not given, but they, by design follow the exact same data structure and definition as their same-named tables in the eco schema (i.e. one can reference the eco schema for metadata on the structure of public schema materialized views).

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Stringham Range Ecology Lab. University of Nevada, Reno.
Stringham Range Ecology Lab Website
Wade Lieurance

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Custom non-DIMA schema table which keeps track of database imports into the schema.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database
The path at which the source database was located during import.
A description of the data source or the type/location/time of data collected.

The md5hash of the source database during import. For fileGDBs, the hash of the individual file hashes, minus the a00000004.gdbtable and a00000004.gdbtablx, a00000004.freelist, timestamps, and any lock files.

Custom non-DIMA schema table which, along with associated triggers/functions, acts as sort of a shim to intercept and store line keys from imported databases. Thus, while each LineKey must be unique in dima.tblLines, this table keeps track of which line keys have been imported from which databases present in the dima.db table. If all records of a line key are completely removed from this table, it will then cascade and be removed from tblLines.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for a transect, generally in the date/time form of YYMMDDHHMMSSRRRR where R is a random digit and the time stamp is when the key was generated.

Custom non-DIMA schema table which, along with associated triggers/functions, acts as sort of a shim to intercept and store plot keys from imported databases. Thus, while each PlotKey must be unique in dima.tblPlots, this table keeps track of which plot keys have been imported from which databases present in the dima.db table. If all records of a plot key are completely removed from this table, it will then cascade and be removed from tblPlots.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for a plot, generally in the date/time form of YYMMDDHHMMSSRRRR where R is a random digit and the time stamp is when the key was generated.

Custom non-DIMA schema table which, along with associated triggers/functions, acts as sort of a shim to intercept and store site keys from imported databases. Thus, while each SiteKey must be unique in dima.tblSites, if a site key has been imported from multiple databases, this table keeps track of which site keys have been imported from which databases present in the dima.db table. If all records of a site key are completely removed from this table, it will then cascade and be removed from tblSites.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database.

A unique alphanumeric string identifier for a site (a geographic, temporal, or categorical grouping variable), generally in the date/time form of YYMMDDHHMMSSRRRR where R is a random digit and the time stamp is when the key was generated.

Custom non-DIMA schema table which, along with associated triggers/functions, acts as sort of a shim to intercept and store inserts into the dima.tblEcolSites table within certain criteria. Base data is inserted into this table at the time of database creation. Records that are inserted into this table after db creation are checked against the base data, if there is a primary key violation and the non-key data to be inserted is not NULL or blank, but is also different than the base data, then the data gets intercepted and stored in this delta table. Data with PK violations but blank or null non-PK fields are not inserted into the delta table. Data with a primary key NOT in the base data get inserted into the delta table without checks. For more detail please see the eco_insert trigger definition on table dima.tblEcolSites.

Custom non-DIMA schema table which, along with associated triggers/functions, acts as sort of a shim to intercept and store inserts into the dima.tblSpeciesGeneric table within certain criteria. Base data is inserted into this table at the time of database creation. Records that are inserted into this table after db creation are checked against the base data, if there is a primary key violation and the non-key data to be inserted is not NULL or blank, but is also different than the base data, then the data gets intercepted and stored in this delta table. Data with PK violations but blank or null non-PK fields are not inserted into the delta table. Data with a primary key NOT in the base data get inserted into the delta table without checks. For more detail please see the generic_insert trigger definition on table dima.tblSpeciesGeneric.

Custom non-DIMA schema table which, along with associated triggers/functions, acts as sort of a shim to intercept and store inserts into the dima.tblSpecies table within certain criteria. Base data is inserted into this table at the time of database creation. Records that are inserted into this table after db creation are checked against the base data, if there is a primary key violation and the non-key data to be inserted is not NULL or blank, but is also different than the base data, then the data gets intercepted and stored in this delta table. Data with PK violations but blank or null non-PK fields are not inserted into the delta table. Data with a primary key NOT in the base data get inserted into the delta table without checks. For more detail please see the species_insert trigger definition on table dima.tblSpecies.
Info on individual data sets imported into the database.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database
The path at which the source database was located during import.
A description of the data source or the type/location/time of data collected.

The md5hash of the source database during import. For fileGDBs, the hash of the individual file hashes, minus the a00000004.gdbtable and a00000004.gdbtablx, a00000004.freelist, timestamps, and any lock files.
Data from the disturbance observation collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The date of the method collection.
This field integrates where the disturbance indicators are and when the disturbance occurred.
Disturbance is in the general area of the plot and has occurred over one year ago.
Disturbance is in the general area of the plot and had occurred within the last year.
Disturbance is within the plot and has occurred over one year ago.
Disturbance is within the plot and and had occurred within the last year.
Spatial and temporal data about the disturbance was not recorded.
Cultivation (plowing, discing, cultivator, chisel plow etc.).
Whether or not the plot or the area around the plot has been hayed.
Mowing (clipping).
Hay removal.
Soil disturbance from heavy machinery.
Seedbed preparation (tillage implements, drill).
Livestock tanks, spring development.
Livestock heavy use area.
Livestock grazing.
Degree of grazing use of the management unit containing the plot.
Currently grazed light (less than 30% harvest)
Currently grazed moderate (30-50% harvest)
Currently grazed heavy (greater than 50% harvest)
Insects.
Rodents.
Non-rodent animals.
Wildlife grazing impacts.
Mining/Energy/equip. and operations.
Recreation (trails, foot traffic).
Recreation (vehicles, bikes).
Livestock walkway, trailing.
Roads/Lanes (dirt).
Roads/lanes (gravel).
Roads/lanes (paved).
Drainage or field ditch.
Underground utilities.
Overhead transmission.
Construction activities (fence, pipeline, terraces etc.).
Water, flooding/ponding.
Soil deposition caused by water.
Soil deposition caused by wind.
Water erosion.
Wind erosion.
Transported fill material.
Wildfire.
Prescribed fire.
Fire fighting (machinery, clearing).
Brush control (chemical).
Brush control (mechanical).
Brush mgt. biological treatment.
Other disturbances not captured in other fields.
A description of the disturbance(s) if other disturbance = True.
Any notes about disturbances on the plot.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V1, Plot Observation, p. 23

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Herrick, J. E., Van Zee, J. W., McCord, S. E., Courtright, E. M., Karl, J. W., & Burkett, L. M. (2017). Monitoring manual for grassland, shrubland and savanna ecosystems (Vol 1: Core Methods) (2nd ed.)

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Department of Agriculture - Agricultural Research Service, Jornada Experimental Range
Monitoring Manual for Grassland, Shrubland, and Savanna Ecosystems, Second Edition. Volume I: Core Methods.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Data about NRCS ecological site(s) identified within a plot during a method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.

The identifier of a particular ecological community found within the plot without the site type prepended (F,R,G). For NRCS ecological sites, it is a concatenation of NRCS Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) symbol, Land Resource Unit(LRU) symbol, site number and state FIPS alpha code.
A single character which identifies the NRCS ecological site type.
Rangeland ecological site.
Forested ecological site.
Grassland ecological site.
The name of the identified ecological site found within the plot.
The estimated percentage of the plot area made up of the ecological site (0, 1]
The rank of the ecosite in terms of percent area, with 1 being the most dominant rank.

The ecological state that the ecosite is in at the the time of method collection according to the State and Transition Diagram found within the NRCS Ecological Site Description for the observed ecosite. Preferably given in the form of {state_number}, {state_label} (e.g. '6, Tree State').

The specific community phase within the ecological state that the plot is in at the the time of method collection according to the State and Transition Diagram found within the Ecological Site Description for the observed ecosite. Preferably given in the form of {state_number.community_number, community label} (e.g. '2.1, At Risk').
A description of the specific community phase given in state_community, including factors that influenced the specific community phase designation.
NRCS ecological sites found within a plot whose boundaries have been collected at the transect level.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the transect on which the data were collected.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The sequence order along the transect at which point the ecological site was encountered.

The identifier of a particular ecological community found within the plot without the site type prepended (F,R,G). For NRCS ecological sites, it is a concatenation of NRCS Major Land Resource Area (MLRA) symbol, Land Resource Unit(LRU) symbol, site number and state FIPS alpha code.
Mark on the transect that the ecological site begins. Units are in transect.transect_units.
Mark on the transect where the ecological site ends. Units are in transect.transect_units.
Data about the Ecological Site Functional Structural Groups method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V2, Chapter 24 State and transition models: an introduction, p. 127

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Herrick, J. E., Van Zee, J. W., Havstad, K. M., Burkett, L. M. & Witford, W.G. (2009). Monitoring manual for grassland, shrubland and savanna ecosystems (Vol II: Design, supplementary methods and interpretation)

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Department of Agriculture - Agricultural Research Service, Jornada Experimental Range
Monitoring Manual for Grassland, Shrubland, and Savanna Ecosystems, Volume II: Design, supplementary methods and interpretation.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Data from the gap intercept method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
An identifier of the types of vegetation that could stop a gap for the collection instance. An instance with multiple rectypes will have multiple record sets per record key, one for each rectype.
Basal. Gaps are between basal cover for perennial species.
Canopy. Gaps are between canopy cover (annual, biennial, and perennial).
Perennial. Gaps are between perennial canopy cover.
An integer which identifies the order in which the gap intercept data were collected.
The start of a qualified gap along the transect in centimeters from the established beginning of the transect.
The end of a qualified gap along the transect in centimeters from the established beginning of the transect.
Data about the gap intercept method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date of the method collection.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
The gap size in centimeters that was used as the minimum possible gap size for the method instance.

An ordered semicolon delimited list of the types of vegetation that could stop a gap for the collection instance. An instance with multiple items will have multiple record sets per record key, one for each gap_type, defined in the rectype field in the gap table.
Gaps are between basal cover for perennial species.
Gaps are between canopy cover (annual, biennial, and perennial).
Gaps are between perennial canopy cover.
A flag stating whether canopy cover stops a gap. Should be True for method instances where either canopy or peren rectypes are present.
A flag stating that canopy/perennial gap was collected, but no gaps were found to be present.
A flag stating whether basal cover stops a gap. Should be True for method instances where either basal rectypes are present.
A flag stating that basal gap was collected, but no gaps were found to be present.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the transect on which the data were collected.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V1, Core Methods, Gap Intercept, p. 41

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Long form note records for the plot.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time the note was recorded.
The "section" that the note corresponds to (e.g., soils, line-point intercept).
Note associated with the LMF Standing Biomass protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Resource Concerns protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Disturbance Indicators protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Ecological Site/Forage Suitability Group Transect Information and Use protocol.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 8. Ecological Site/Forage Suitability Transect Information and Use, p. 46.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout protocol. Specifically referring to notes about position data.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 3. Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout, p. 10.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout protocol. Specifically referring to notes about site access/accessibility.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 3. Point Location and Plot/Transect Layout, p. 10.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Land Cover/Use protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Gap Intercept: Basal and Canopy Gaps protocol.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 10. Gap Intercept: Basal and Canopy Gaps, p. 59.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: General notes about the plot.
Note associated with the LMF Plant Height protocol.
Note associated with LMF protocol practice.
Note associated with the LMF Species Composition by Weight protocol (Non-Federal Rangeland Only).

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 14. Species Composition by Weight, p. 82.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Line Point Transects for Cover Composition protocol.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Chapter 9. Line Point Transects for Cover Composition, p. 52.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Note associated with the LMF Rangeland Health protocol (Rangeland only).
Note associated with the LMF Sagebrush Shape protocol (Rangeland only).
Note associated with the LMF Landscape and Soils protocol.
Note associated with the LMF Soil Stability Test protocol.

Note associated with the LMF Plant Census protocol, specifically in relation to an unknown/unidentified plant. This a generalized value pertaining to a set of values all starting with 'unknownPlant2' and ending with a USDA Unknown Plant Code and a sequence number (e.g. 1, 2, 3, etc.).
Long form note.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
Detail records associated with the line-point intercept method which includes plant cover, height, and decadence measurements.
A unique site identifier for each method collection instance.
This refers to the point along the transect in units of that transect (See transect.transect_units).
An integer designating the layer order of the vegetation layer hit, with 1 being the topmost (tallest) layer.
A code abbreviation designating if the hit was a layer hit or nearby vegetation selected by growth habit.
Layer hit. The hit is part of the vertical structure cross-sectioned by the measuring device (pin, laser, etc.). These are the only type of hits that can be used to measure point-intercept cover

Growth habit hit. The hit is not from the vertical cross sectional area but is chosen from nearby vegetation according to methodology parameters, generally for the purpose of measuring height. These types of hits cannot be used to measure point-intercept cover.
A code abbreviation designating what category a hit falls under.
Top. The hit is part of the cross sectional layer and is the top hit.
Lower. The hit is part of the cross sectional layer and is neither the top or surface hit.
Surface. The hit is part of the cross sectional layer and is the lowest hit (i.e. surface or basal).
Herbaceous. The hit is not part of the cross sectional layer and falls within herbaceous criteria.
Woody. The hit is not part of the cross sectional layer and falls within woody criteria.
A code referring to the vegetation layer "hit" for a hit order at a mark.
NRCS PLANTS plant codes.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: USDA, NRCS. The PLANTS Database. National Plant Data Team, Greensboro, NC 27401-4901 USA.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Department of Agriculture Natural Resource Conservation Service
The PLANTS Database.

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: The PLANTS Database provides standardized information about the vascular plants, mosses, liverworts, hornworts, and lichens of the U.S. and its territories.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: AIM non-USDA PLANT codes.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Table 15. A list of columns that can be populated as part of Line-point intercept, along with a list of permitted options for each column. p.30

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The plant height, in centimeters for a hit order at a mark.
A boolean flag which indicates whether the portion of vegetation layer hit is dead.
Data about the line-point intercept method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date of the method collection.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the transect on which the data were collected.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Records of plants found during the plant census collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The order that a species was documented during the census.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
Any notes about a specific species, such as identifying characteristics in that case that the code is an unknown code.
Data about the plant census collection instance. Check methodology documentation for time searched.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
The size of the plot on which the method was conducted in square meters.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V1, Core Methods, Plant Species Inventory, p. 55

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Data from the plant density method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The unique alphanumeric subplot identifier for a transect.
An NRCS plant species code for the plant being measured.
A number identifying a specific plant class definition.
The total count of a plant species of a certain class within a subplot.
Data about the plant classes used during the plant density method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
A number identifying a specific plant class definition.
A label describing the class (e. g. seedlings, forbs, dead, etc.).
Data about the plant density method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date of the method collection.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
The number of sub-plots established on a transect for a method instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A description of the type of plants searched for (e.g. forbs, perennial grasses, etc.) or a semicolon delimited list of specific USDA plant codes searched for.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the transect on which the data were collected.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V2, Ch. 15, Density, frequency and Line-point intercept alternative methods, p. 84

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Data about the subplots established during the plant density method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.

The unique alphanumeric subplot identifier for the subplot on a trancsect. An common example of the need for this field would be when there are 10 sq. m quadrats labeled 1-10 and a single 50 sq. m belt transect for each line. Then the subplot ids for the quadrats and belt transects could look like '1_1m', '2_1m' and '1_50m' respecively.
A number indicating the ordinal establishment of the subplot along the transect.
The size of the subplot in square meters.
Data for a single plot/point and its establishment protocol(s).
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.
A label/identifier for the plot.
The survey year for which the plot was generated as part of a survey panel.
The date of the establishment of the plot.
The Current state Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code for the state where the plot is located.

gfc:label.gco:CharacterString: National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States/State Equivalents

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The Current county Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code for the county where the plot is located.

gfc:label.gco:CharacterString: National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The symbol identifier for an NRCS Major Land Resource Area that the plot falls geographically within.
Three character abbreviation for the surface ownership on which the plot falls.
The primary category of the landform on which the plot primarily falls.
The secondary category of the landform on which the plot primarily falls.
The down slope shape of the plot location.
Slope Shape

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Schoeneberger, P.J., D.A. Wysocki, E.C. Benham, and Soil Staff. 2012. Field book for describing and sampling soils, Version 3.0. Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Soil Center, Lincoln, NE

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The across slope shape of the plot location.
Slope Shape
The percent slope (vertical change / horizontal change) of the plot ranging from 0 to 100.

The slope length is defined as the distance from the point of origin of overland flow to the point where either the slope gradient decreases enough that soil deposition begins or the runoff water enters a well-defined channel that may be part of a drainage network or constructed channel. Units are in transect units (See transect_transect_units).
The aspect of the slope, or the down slope direction toward which a slope faces measured using a compass, of a plot. Aspect is in degrees ranging from 0-359.
Latitude for the plot center in decimal degrees, WGS 84 datum, where negative values are for southern hemisphere.
Longitude for the plot center in decimal degrees, WGS 84 datum, where negative values are for western hemisphere.
Elevation for the plot center in meters.

Indicates whether field GPS points were captured. If "successful", then the field crew was able to capture a location with GPS on their electronic data capture device; if "poor GPS", the field crew was unable to capture a GPS location using their electronic data capture device.
The full time zone name found in the IANA timezone database (See Also pg_timezone_names table).
Alphanumeric codes associated with each named Major Land Resource Area.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) Time Zone Database

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority. Public Technical Identifiers. Retrieved 28 May 2021 from https://www.iana.org/

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Latitude, longitude, elevation, and datum converted to PointZ data type. Horizontal Datum: WGS 84 (srid 4326).
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the site to which a plot belongs.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V1, Plot Characterization, p. 16

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Plant biomass production data.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
An NRCS plant species code for the plant being measured.
The subplot number in which the data are collected.

The number of units of production estimated for the plant. Units are a specific estimation weight given for each species, in grams, found in the production_species.unit_wgt_g field. E.g. Three units with a unit_wgt_g of five would have a mass of 15 grams.
A flag indicating that a species was found at a subplot, but that its production is trace.
The weight of the clipped vegetation (current year's growth), in grams for that species at a subplot (when double sampling).
Data about the annual plant biomass production method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.
The number of subplots used for the method collection instance.
Any notes collected about the method collection instance that are particular to the method collection itself.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V2, Ch. 9, Plant Production, p. 56

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Data about individual species measured during the annual plant biomass production method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
The subplot size in square meters that was used for a species.

The weight in grams for a production estimation unit for a species. An estimation unit is a counted unit made up of a certain estimated mass, e.g. three units with a unit_wgt_g of five would have a mass of 15 grams.
The air dry weight adjustment factor, an adjustment which will convert green weight to air dry weight.
The utilization adjustment factor. This is the percentage of the plant remaining after livestock/wildlife grazing has occurred.
The proportion of the total expected growth that the plant has experienced this season.

The climate adjustment factor for a species, where one would be "normal" climatic conditions. Values above one would indicate climate conditions exceeded normal, opposite for those values less than one (e.g. a value of 1.2 would indicate climatic conditions producing 20% more than "normal" year.)
Data about the subplots established during the annual plant biomass production method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The subplot number in which the data are collected.
A description of where the subplot is located within the plot.
A flag indicating that this subplot was expanded for one size to another for certain or all species.
A flag indicating that this subplot was not sampled, despite its inclusion in the design.
Data from a Interpreting/Describing Indicators of Rangeland Health method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
A number identifying a specific indicator or attribute rated, 1-17 for established indicators, 17+ for custom indicators, and 100, 200, 300 for attributes.
An indicator or attribute name abbreviation.
Rills
Water Flow Patterns
Pedestals and/or Terracettes
Bare Ground
Gullies
Wind-Scoured and/or Depositional Areas
Litter Movement (Wind or Water)
Soil Surface Resistance to Erosion
Soil Surface Loss and Degradation
Effects of Plant Community Composition and Distribution on Infiltration
Compaction Layer
Functional/Structural (F/S) Groups
Plant Mortality and Decadence (Dead or Dying Plants or Plant Parts)
Litter Amount (Litter Cover and Depth)
Annual Production
Invasive Plants
Reproductive Capability of Perennial Plants (Vigor with an Emphasis on)
Soil/Site Stability
Hydrologic Function
Biotic Integrity
A flag indicating whether the record is for an indicator or attribute.
Indicator
Attribute
The rating given to an indicator or attribute.
None to Slight departure from reference.
Slight to Moderate departure from reference.
Moderate departure from reference.
Moderate to Extreme departure from reference.
Extreme to Total departure from reference.
Any notes documenting the the state of the indicator or attribute.
Data about the Interpreting/Describing Indicators of Rangeland Health method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The date and time of the method collection instance.
The (preferably) full name(s) or initials of the person measuring for the collection instance.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code. Primary key for this table, it differs from the ecoid field in that ecological site type (range, forest, etc.) has been stripped. Any underscores and trailing numerical identifiers, if present, are also stripped.
The source of the reference sheet used in the evaluation (e.g. NRCS, other agency name).
The published date of the reference sheet used in the evaluation.
The full name or initials of the reference sheet author(s).
The date that the reference sheet was acquired from the distributor.
The methodology which was used to weight the individual indicators for attribute ratings.
Indicator weights are determined ad hoc and not specifically defined, but based on the the conditions of the site and each individual attribute.
Indicators are all given equal weight in the attribute rating.
Indicators weights are defined and sourced from a specific agency or organization.
Indicators weights are defined and developed by the user or unofficial source.
In the case that indicator weights are either downloaded or user defined, then the name or abbreviation for the source of those weights (e.g. NRCS).
The criteria that was used (if applicable) to select the evaluated area as representative of the wider site conditions.
For indicators 10 (Effects of Plant Community Composition and Distribution on Infiltration) and 12 (Functional/ Structural [F/S] Groups), which methodology was used to determine plant composition.
Annual production was used for plant composition.
Cover was used for plant composition.
Total biomass was used for plant composition.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot at which the data were collected.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Monitoring Manual V1, Core Methods, Plant Species Inventory, p. 55

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Pellant, M., Shaver, P. L., Pyke, D. A., Herrick, J. E., Lepak, N., Riegel, G., Kachergis, E., Newingham, B. A., Toledo, D., & Busby, F.E. 2020. Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health, Version 5. Tech Ref 1734-6. U.S. Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management, National Operations Center, Denver, CO.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: U.S. Department of the Interior, Bureau of Land Management, National Operations Center, Denver, CO.
Interpreting Indicators of Rangeland Health, Version 5. Tech Ref 1734-6.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Detail records associated with the line-point intercept method which includes shrub shape.
A unique site identifier for each method collection instance.
This refers to the point along the transect in units of that transect (See transect.transect_units).
An NRCS species code for the shrub being measured.
The categorical shape of the shrub being measured.
Columnar. Length of base stems have roughly same length as top stems.
Mixed. Shape of the shrub is a mix of columnar and spreading shapes.
Spreading. Length of the stems generally increase and spread out as the canopy gains height.
The Sites associated with the point/plot records.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the site to which a plot belongs.
The short name/label of the site.
A longer description for the site.
Any data about the ownership related to the site.
The specific source of the site data (e.g. Entity Name, Program Name, Dataset Name).
The collection database type that this site is from.
Source data are from USDA ARS Jornada's Database for Inventory, Monitoring and Assessment (DIMA) schema, or was converted to this schema before distribution.
Source data are from a Natural Resources Inventory (NRI) or Landscape Monitoring Framework (LMF) schema, or was converted to this schema before distribution.
Source data are from the native LLEIAdb schema, or was converted to this schema before distribution.
Name of the person(s) that this site is associated with (e.g. owner name, agency personnel, etc.) whom can be contacted regarding this questions about the site.
Any notes that are specific to the site level.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the source database
Data describing the horizons of a soil.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
A sequential number identifying each of the soil horizons described at the site. Sequence number ascends as horizon depth increases.
The depth from the soil surface to the upper break of the described soil horizon in centimeters.
The depth from the soil surface to the lower break of the described soil horizon in centimeters.
The soil taxonomic horizon designation (e.g A, Btk)
NRCS Horizon and Layer Designations Codes
The hue of the soil (dry) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The value of the soil (dry) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart.
The chroma of the soil (dry) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart.
The hue of the soil (wet) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Munsell Color (Firm). (2010). Munsell soil color charts : with genuine Munsell color chips. Grand Rapids, MI :Munsell Color

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Munsell Color

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The value of the soil (wet) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart.
The chroma of the soil (wet) as determined with a Munsell Soil Color Chart.
The percent of surface area covered in a concentration for gravel fragment classes.
Concentrations - Quantity
The NRCS pedogenic carbonate accumulation stage.
Pedogenic Carbonate Stage Description
Flag that indicates presence of clay films on peds.
Ped and Void Surface Features - Kind
The NASIS code for the soil texture of the horizon.
NRCS Texture Class Codes
NASIS Soil horizon modifier code for rock content (cobbly, etc).
NRCS Texture Modifier Codes
A flag indicating whether the soil horizon is gypsic or not
NRCS Compositional Texture Modifier Codes
The percent by volume of discrete, water-stable particles greater than 2 mm.
A flag indicating whether the soil horizon is petrocalcic or not
NRCS Fragment Cementation Status
The primary structure of the soil. Structure is the naturally occurring arrangement of soil particles into aggregates that results from pedogenic processes.
NRCS Soil Structure Codes (NASIS)
The primary grade of the soil structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Grade Codes
The primary size class of the soil structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Size Codes (NASIS)
The verbiage describing how the primary structure transitions to the secondary structure (e.g. 'parting to' or 'over').
NRCS Soil Structure compound description.
The secondary structure of the soil in a compound structure. Structure is the naturally occurring arrangement of soil particles into aggregates that results from pedogenic processes.
NRCS Soil Structure Codes (NASIS)
The secondary grade of the soil in a compound structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Grade Codes
The secondary size class of the soil in a compound structure.
NRCS Soil Structure Size Codes (NASIS)
The NRCS rupture resistance codes for blocks, peds, clods.
NRCS rupture resistance codes for blocks, peds, clods.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Size class code for roots.

The quantity class of a specific root size.
NRCS Quantity Class description for root and pores.
Size class code for pores.
NRCS NASIS code for root and pore size.
The quantity class of a specific poor size.
NRCS Quantity Class description for root and pores.
pH for the soil horizon.
Effervescence class code.
NRCS Effervescence Class Codes
"Calcium carbonate equivalent" is the quantity of carbonate (CO3) in the soil expressed as CaCO3 and as a weight percentage of the less than 2 mm size fraction.
The quantity of the soil by weight percentage of the less than 2 mm size fraction which is calcium sulfate dihydrate.
The electrical conductivity of the soil horizon, in units of decisiemens per meter (dS/m).
The Sodium Adsorption Ratio of the soil horizon. A measure of ion equilibrium between sodium (Na) in solution and exchangeable Na adsorbed on the soil (Soil Survey Staff, 2011).
Any long form note or comment pertaining to the soil horizon.
Stores fragment and sand/silt/clay values for estimated and lab analysis.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
A sequential number identifying each of the soil horizons described at the site. Sequence number ascends as horizon depth increases.
A category label which identifies whether the values in the record are field estimates or lab results.
data are the result of a laboratory analysis.
Data are the result of a measurement or estimate in the field, or otherwise not subject to lab grade analysis.
The NASIS soil component or fragment code of the record.
Sand.
Silt.
Clay.
Gravel.
Cobble.
Stone.
carbonate nodules.
Durinodes.
The fractional percent by volume of the horizon which is made up by the component.
Estimate the relative roundness of rock fragments.
NRCS Roundness Class Codes
The fractional percent of the total volume of the component which can be classified as "very fine" size.
The fractional percent of the total volume of the component which can be classified as "fine" size.
The fractional percent of the total volume of the component which can be classified as "medium" size.
The fractional percent of the total volume of the component which can be classified as "coarse" size.

Records storing data about the soil description methodology or about the soil pit specifically.

The date and time that the pit was described.

A description of where the soil pit was located/dug.

The symbol used to uniquely identify the soil map unit (in the soil survey within the NRCS SSURGO database), in which the soil pit is located.
The taxonomic description of the soil pedon. Description can be as general as an Order and as specific as a Family.

The name of the soil component as which the soil has been identified. Preferably in long format containing the series, surface texture, and slope percentage.
The unique component key identifying the component in the NRCS SSURGO database.
An integer which describes the confidence rating a crew has with a soil ID. Primarily used by NRI, the integer value remains undefined in the method documentation.
Any long form comments or notes that are associated with the completion of the soil description methodology.
Longitude for the plot center in decimal degrees, WGS 84 datum, where negative values are for western hemisphere.
Latitude for the plot center in decimal degrees, WGS 84 datum, where negative values are for southern hemisphere.
Elevation for the plot center in meters.
Latitude, longitude, elevation, and datum converted to PointZ data type. Horizontal Datum: WGS 84 (srid 4326).
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
Data from the soil stability method collection instance.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
In the case that multiple boxes of peds were collected, the box number that the sample belongs to.
The cell number of the collection box that the ped was placed in (1-18).
In the case that the sample was collected along a line, which line id it was collected on.
In the case that the sample was collected along a line, the line position it was collected at, in units of the transect (transect.transect_units).

Root mat.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: 50% of structural integrity lost (melts) within 5 seconds of immersion in water, AND < 10% remains after 5 dipping cycles, OR soil too unstable to sample (falls through sieve).
50% of structural integrity lost (melts) 5-30 seconds after immersion AND < 10% remains after 5 dipping cycles.
50% of structural integrity lost (melts) 30-300 seconds after immersion, OR < 10% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles.
1025% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles.
2575% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles.
75100% of soil remains on the sieve after five dipping cycles.

The md5hash of the source database during import. For fileGDBs, the hash of the individual file hashes, minus the a00000004.gdbtable and a00000004.gdbtablx, a00000004.freelist, timestamps, and any lock files.
County data from the U.S. Census Bureau's Current County and Equivalent National Dataset.
County identifier; a concatenation of Current state FIPS code and county FIPS code.

The GEOID attribute is a concatenation of the state FIPS code followed by the county FIPS code. No spaces are allowed between the two codes. The State FIPS code is taken from "National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 38-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - States". The county FIPS code is taken from "National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents".

Current county Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code.

Current county name.
National Standard Codes (ANSI INCITS 31-2009), Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) - Counties/County Equivalents.

NRCS ecological sites which may be associated with a plot.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code. Primary key for this table, it differs from the ecoid field in that ecological site type (range, forest, etc.) has been stripped. Any underscores and trailing numerical identifiers, if present, are also stripped.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, it is the concatenated form of ecological site type, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code.

The descriptive name of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, it is the concatenated form of three or six other fields. The actual fields that are concatenated together to form this name differ between range and forest ecological sites.
The ecological site type.
Range.
Forest

The NRCS Land Resource Unit code associated with an ecological site.

The type/category/name of the user custom ecological grouping.
USDA PLANTS database plant list.
A 3 to 7 digit alphanumeric code which uniquely identifies a genus, species, subspecies, etc. within the PLANTS database.
Identifies the taxonomic category in which the plant code falls (Genus, Species, Subspecies, Variety, Forma).

The scientific name associated with the plant in binomial nomenclature (without author). Scientific Names also sometimes will have trinomial or quadrinomial names associated with botanical nomenclature.
A common name for the plant (non-scientific).
The taxonomic Family to which the plant belongs. A sub-taxon of Order.

The plant life cycle length. Some plants have different durations depending on environment or location, so a plant can have more than one value. Multiple values are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download Notes. 3. Ecology: Duration.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The plant's entire life cycle, from seed to flower to seed, within a single growing season.
Plants which require two years to complete their life cycle.
Plants that persist for many growing seasons.
Refers to the shape, height, appearance, and form of growth of a plant species.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download Notes. 3. Ecology: Growth Habit

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: NRCS Growth Habit Codes and Definitions code list.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: NRCS Growth Habit Codes and Definitions

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Growth Habits Codes and Definitions

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: A code list and definition set for Growth Habit in the USDA NRCS PLANTS database.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The status of a plants distribution in an area and its relationship to the historic populations within that area.

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download. 3. Ecology: Native Status

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Native Status and Native Status Jurisdiction code list in the form of "NativeStatusJurisdiction(NativeStatus)". Multiple jurisdictions are separated via a comma.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Native Status and Native Status Jurisdiction codes

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Native Status

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: We have broken the PFA into Native Status jurisdictions to try to improve our information about where plants are native. A plant that is native to any part of a Native Status jurisdiction (e.g., L48, the lower 48 states) is considered Native, even if some populations within that area are introduced. Thus the L48 Native Status value for smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora) is N (Native) despite the existence of introduced populations on the West Coast. However, a plant like dandelion (Taraxacum officinale) is considered Native and Introduced since it has some infra-taxa that are native to L48 and some that are introduced there. Plants that do not occur in the PFA do not have Native Status values in PLANTS, though they may be cultivated or used as ornamentals within the PFA.

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The indicator used before the genus name in the "scientific_name" field () which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two genera.
The genus name of the plant, the first half of the scientific name in biniomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Family.
The indicator used before the species name in the "scientific_name" field () which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two species.
The species name of the plant, the second half of the scientific name in biniomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Genus.
The indicator used before the subspecies name in the "scientific_name" field (ssp.) which indicates that this plant is a subspecies of another species.
The indicator used before the subspecies name (but after the subspecies prefix) in the "scientific_name" field () which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two subspecies.
The subspecies name of the plant, the third portion of the scientific name in trinomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Species.
The indicator used before the subspecies name in the "scientific_name" field (var.) which indicates that this plant is a variety (varietas) of another species.
The indicator used before the variety name (but after the variety prefix) in the "scientific_name" field () which indicates that this plant is a hybrid of two varieties.

The variety name of the plant, the third portion of the scientific name in trinomial nomenclature. A taxonomic category that ranks below Subspecies. It is sometimes recommended that the subspecies rank should be used to recognize geographic distinctiveness, whereas the variety rank is appropriate if the taxon is seen throughout the geographic range of the species.
The indicator used before the form name in the "scientific_name" field (f.) which indicates that this plant is a form (forma) of another species/subspecies/variety.
The form name of the plant, the third or fourth portion of the scientific name in the botanical ternary naming system. A taxonomic category that ranks below Variety.

The author citation of the species. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.
Botanist author name abbreviations.

cit:title.gco:CharacterString: Brummitt, R. K.; Powell, C. E., eds. (1992). Authors of Plant Names: a List of Authors of Scientific Names of Plants, with Recommended Standard Forms of their Names, Including Abbreviations. Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: List of botanists by author abbreviation (A)

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: The author citation of the trinomial taxon (subspecies, variety, etc.) in the ternary name of botanical nomenclature. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.

The author citation of the quadrinomial taxon (e.g. form) in the ternary name of botanical nomenclature. In botanical nomenclature, author citation refers to citing the person or group of people who validly published a botanical name, i.e. who first published the name while fulfilling the formal requirements as specified by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN). In cases where a species is no longer in its original generic placement (i.e. a new combination of genus and specific epithet), both the author(s) of the original genus placement and those of the new combination are given (the former in parentheses). In botany, it is customary (though not obligatory) to abbreviate author names according to a recognized list of standard abbreviations.
In the case that a plant is a hybrid, gives the hybrid parents.
The distribution of the plant within U.S. States, Territories, and Protectorates; Canada Provinces and Territories; Greenland (Denmark), and St. Pierre and Miquelon (France).

gfc:sourceIdentifier.gco:CharacterString: Advanced Search and Download. 1. Distribution: State and Province

gfc:definition.gco:CharacterString: Distribution codes. State/Province identifiers occur as a comma separated list in the form of "CountryCode(State/Province)

cit:name.gco:CharacterString: Distribution

cit:description.gco:CharacterString: The PLANTS database contains native and naturalized plants of the PLANTS Floristic Area (PFA), which consists of North America and all additional U.S. territories and protectorates. Vascular plant distributions are mapped at the state and province level, and by U.S. county. Our checklists for the non-vascular mosses, liverworts, hornworts, and lichens cover all of North America north of Mexico; no additional distribution data are currently available for these plants. Checklist and plant distribution by island and island group for the U.S. territories and protectorates in the PFA Pacific Basin area are in preparation but are not yet included at PLANTS. The total number of PFA accepted taxa at the rank of binomial and below is about 38,000. PLANTS also has about 5000 vascular plants that do not occur spontaneously (i.e., are not naturalized) in the PFA; these are selected if you choose Not in PLANTS Floristic Area. Most of these are of economic importance, and many of them are cultivated within the PFA.

A view which calculates gap indicators at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.

An identifier of the types of vegetation that could stop a gap for the collection instance. An instance with multiple rectypes will have multiple record sets per plot key and survey_year, one for each rectype.
Basal. Gaps are between basal cover for perennial species.
Canopy. Gaps are between canopy cover (annual, biennial, and perennial).
Perennial. Gaps are between perennial canopy cover.

An identifier of the types of vegetation that could stop a gap for the collection instance. An instance with multiple rectypes will have multiple record sets per plot key and survey_year, one for each rectype.
Basal. Gaps are between basal cover for perennial species.
Canopy. Gaps are between canopy cover (annual, biennial, and perennial).
Perennial. Gaps are between perennial canopy cover.
The number of line method collection instances summarized.
The mean number of gaps detected of all line method instances.
The sample standard deviation of the number of gaps detected of all line method instances.
The mean gap size in centimeters of all line method instances.
The sample standard deviation gap size in centimeters of all line method instances.
The mean fractional percentage of the line that is made up of gaps across all line method instances.
The sample standard deviation of the fractional percent of the line that is made up of gaps across all line method instances.
The fractional percent of total gaps that are made up of gaps > 0 cm and <= 20 cm.
The fractional percent of total gaps that are made up of gaps > 20 cm and <= 50 cm.
The fractional percent of total gaps that are made up of gaps > 50 cm and <= 100 cm.
The fractional percent of total gaps that are made up of gaps > 100 cm and <= 200 cm.
The fractional percent of total gaps that are made up of gaps > 200 cm.

The is a view which produces fields similar to the public.plant_mod view, but sources its species codes from the data of method data that use species codes. Regex is used on these codes to separate the "unknown" portion of the plant codes from the base codes and attach growth habits ad durations based on those modified parts (e.g. AF for annual forb or PG for perennial grass). For undocumented field definitions, please see public.plant documentation.
The USDA plant code sourced from either public.plant or from the method data.
The portion of the species_code that matches an accepted_symbol in public.plants.
The numerical portion of the species_code that is generally appended to an accepted_symbol in method data which denotes that it is an unidentified subcategory of that code.
The duration matching the text portion of the species_code that regex matching has identified as either a prepended or appended duration code.
The growth habit matching the text portion of the species_code that regex matching has identified as either a prepended or appended growth habit code.

A view which calculates line-point intercept indicators at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.
Text designating if the hit was a layer hit or nearby vegetation selected by growth habit.
Layer hit. The hit is part of the vertical structure cross-sectioned by the measuring device (pin, laser, etc.). These are the only type of hits that can be used to measure point-intercept cover

Growth habit hit. The hit is not from the vertical cross sectional area but is chosen from nearby vegetation according to methodology parameters, generally for the purpose of measuring height. These types of hits cannot be used to measure point-intercept cover.

The number of line method collection instances of a particular hit/hit_type. This should be the same number of method instances for a plot/year as zero has been imputed for method instances within a plot/year where that hit/hit_type was missing before summarizing.

The mean fractional percentage of a particular hit/hit_type across line method collection instances (out of the total hits for an instance). Zero has been imputed for missing instance values before summarizing.

The sample standard deviation of the fractional percentage of a particular hit/hit_type across line method collection instances (out of the total hits for an instance). Zero has been imputed for missing instance values before summarizing.
The number of line method collection instances of a particular hit/hit_type which had dead data. May be less than total instances.
The mean fractional percentage of dead cover for a particular hit/hit_type across line method collection instances.
The sample standard deviation of the fractional percentage of dead cover for a particular hit/hit_type across line method collection instances.
The number of line method collection instances of a particular hit/hit_type which had height data. May be less than total instances.
The mean height in centimeters for a particular hit/hit_type across line method collection instances.
The sample standard deviation of the height in centimeters for a particular hit/hit_type across line method collection instances.

This is a view which produces fields similar to the public.plant table, but adds a couple of calculated fields for convenience. For undocumented field definitions, please see public.plant documentation.

The first duration in the comma/space delimited list given in a code's duration field, which according to NRCS is supposed to be the most common duration found in floras referenced for the USDA PLANTS database.

The first growth habit in the comma/space delimited list given in a code's growth_habit field, which according to NRCS is supposed to be the most common growth habit found in floras referenced for the USDA PLANTS database.

This is a view which produces identical fields to the public.plant_mod view, but adds a number of records. Essentially this is union of the public.plant table, the public.method_species_regex view, and a compilation of six digit plant family codes created from the public.plant table. Generally, this view will be the one used to join method calculations for species codes to their attributes instead of the public.plant table due to its inclusion of family codes and unknown plant codes oftentimes found in method data. Please see public.plant_mod documentation for field definitions.

A view which summarizes plant census species at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
The number of line method collection instances summarized.
Individual species codes notes, aggregated for each code and delimited by a semicolon then a space.
A view which summarizes plant density at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.
A number identifying a specific plant class definition.
A label describing the class (e. g. seedlings, forbs, dead, etc.).
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
The number of line method collection instances summarized.
The mean density in units of plants/hectare of a particular species code across line method collection instances. Zero has been imputed for missing instance values before summarizing.

The sample standard deviation of the density in units of plants/hectare of a particular species code across line method collection instances. Zero has been imputed for missing instance values before summarizing.
A view which summarizes annual production at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
The number of line method collection instances summarized.
The annual production in units of grams per square meter of a particular species code across line method collection instances. Zero has been imputed for missing instance values before summarizing.

The sample standard deviation of the annual production in units of grams per square meter of a particular species code across line method collection instances. Zero has been imputed for missing instance values before summarizing.
Data from a Interpreting/Describing Indicators of Rangeland Health method collection instance, transformed to wide format, with plot and date metadata added.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The date and time of the method collection instance.

The identifier of a particular ecological community. For NRCS ecological sites, ecological site MLRA, ecological site LRU, ecological site number and ecological site state FIPS alpha code. Primary key for this table, it differs from the ecoid field in that ecological site type (range, forest, etc.) has been stripped. Any underscores and trailing numerical identifiers, if present, are also stripped.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the method collection instance.
The rating for indicator 1: Rills.
The rating for indicator 1: Rills.
The rating for indicator 2: Water Flow Patterns.
The rating for indicator 3: Pedestals and/or Terracettes.
The rating for indicator 4: Bare Ground.
The rating for indicator 5: Gullies.
The rating for indicator 6: Wind-Scoured and/or Depositional Areas.
The rating for indicator 7: Litter Movement (Wind or Water).
The rating for indicator 8: Soil Surface Resistance to Erosion.
The rating for indicator 9: Soil Surface Loss and Degradation.
The rating for indicator 10: Effects of Plant Community Composition and Distribution on Infiltration.
The rating for indicator 11: Compaction Layer.
The rating for indicator 12: Functional/Structural (F/S) Groups.
The rating for indicator 13: Plant Mortality and Decadence (Dead or Dying Plants or Plant Parts).
The rating for indicator 14: Litter Amount (Litter Cover and Depth).
The rating for indicator 15: Annual Production.
The rating for indicator 16: Invasive Plants.
The rating for indicator 17: Reproductive Capability of Perennial Plants (Vigor with an Emphasis on).
The rating for attribute 1: Soil/Site Stability.
The rating for attribute 2: Hydrologic Function.
The rating for attribute 3: Biotic Integrity.

A view which summarizes shrub shape data (from the line-point intercept method) at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.
The categorical shape of the shrub being measured.
Length of base stems have roughly same length as top stems.
Shape of the shrub is a mix of columnar and spreading shapes.
Length of the stems generally increase and spread out as the canopy gains height.
The NRCS plant code of a plant species.
The number of line method collection instances summarized. Can be fewer than number of total instances.
The fractional mean of a particular species code/shape across line method collection instances.
The sample standard deviation of the fractional mean of a particular species code/shape across line method collection instances.
A view which summarizes soil stability data at the plot/year level. Join to the public.point (plotkey) table and then to the public.site (sitekey) table for plot and site level metadata respectively.
A unique alphanumeric string identifier for the plot.
The year in which the survey was completed.
What types of peds were sampled.
Only surface peds were collected.
Both surface and subsurface peds were collected, each as their own method instance.
The number of plot method collection instances summarized.
The mean rating of a particular veg code across plot method collection instances.
The sample standard deviation of the rating of a particular veg code across plot method collection instances.
